My idea:

In both scenarios the same amount of energy is being imparted in the block.

The scenario where the rifle is aimed towards the middle of the block simply shoots the block straight upwards.

The scenario where the rifle is aimed towards the right of the block comparatively shoots it upwards less, but also causes rotational energy that stabilizes the block, resulting in the energy being less erratic/inefficient similar to the rifling of a gun barrel.

It’s the same amount of energy either way, but because the wood block isn’t inside of a barrel, both scenarios result in identical - or close to it - heights.

Hey, the forces of interaction between the bullet and the block are internal forces, so the net change in momentum is zero in both. And the the total initial momentum equals total final momentum.
On the other hand the rotational kinetic energy come from the loss in KE of the bullet, this loss in the first case was completely dissipated, whereas in the second case this loss is partially used in the rotation of the block.
So here's what I think and what probably should be the correct explaination.

Ik it's 7 years later and the right answer is alerdy probably published.... My explanation is as follows.
Since the bullet is hitting the block 'normally' the force exerted by the bullet on the block in both scenarios is identical. So the height achieved is also identical. About the spin... Assuming the nail is in the 'centre of mass', the uniform rotating body's angular momentum at one end is also equal to the angular momentum at the same point at the other end. Effectively canceling out. Hence we don't need to worry about the spin in this scenario to calculate height achieved. If the angle of incidence of the bullet is changed, then only there would be difference in height.
Both blocks have rotational energy... just on different axis.

Just to make sure you are aware, but snipers get what they call "matched" ammunition when doing their 'job'. The ammo that comes off the line is all generally the same amount of powder and whatnot, however the slightest differences in the ammo will change the results. True snipers will weigh up the exact amount of powder used grain for grain and make sure that every single shot they put down range at a target (paper/metal or live) will preform the same exact way, or change the ammo however needed to account for specific variables such as distance to target, wind speed, humidity/moisture levels in the air as well as on/around the weapon, Coriolis effect, etc...


I do not claim to be a scientist or sniper, or that i know what i stated above would affect the outcome, however its possible. just something to consider

I believe Veritasium's answers are incorrect. Here is my theory.  When the bullet strikes the block off-center, the block begins to spin.  As the block begins to spin, the block acts as a lever and the nail pushes downward against the plexiglass stand.  The plexiglass structure sits on solid ground, so as the nail pushes downward against it, the effective result is the nail is helping to launch the block upward (just as anything that gives the earth a downward shove will itself experience an upward acceleration).  To prove my theory, you can do the experiment again, removing the plexiglass stand at the exact moment of bullet contact (I'm not sure how this could be done).  Or more easily you could suspend the block using a squishy support structure instead of the rigid plexiglass. If you do this the result will be much different, and the spinning block will not go as high as the non-spinning block.

Для большей наглядности различий в глубине проникновения пуль необходимо придать бруску форму, которая будет характеризоваться: 1)неоднородным по высоте, но симметричным относительно оси симметрии распределением массы.
2) масса центральной части бруска над центром его основания должна быть больше чем масса каждого из краев по отдельности.
Меньшая масса края бруска дает увеличение ускорения приобретаемого им относительно края бруска обычной формы при выстреле в край основания, соответственно скорость вращения бруска будет выше, а это будет означать, что большая часть кинетической энергии пули перейдет в энергию вращения бруска, нежели в случае выстрела в край обычного бруска в форме прямоугольного параллелепипеда. Переход намного большей части кинетической энергии пули в энергию вращения при выстреле в край бруска даст большую разницу при сравнении глубин отверстий оставленных пулями выстреленными в центр его основания и в край.
Как частный случай можно взять т-образный брусок, подвешенный шляпкой вверх на гвозди вставленные в нижнюю часть его ножки. Чтобы показать, что значительный рост скорости вращения в случае выстрела в т-образный брусок не связан с изменением массы при переходе от бруска обычной формы, а является именно следствием уменьшения количества энергии идущей на деформацию тела бруска можно сделать брусок из материала более плотного чем тот из которого был сделан исходный брусок.

The total energy of both the objects remain the same because they were both struck by the same force.

In the first block,the energy was conserved by converting all of it into linear momentum.
There might have also been a small amount of angular momentum because the bullet can never strike the centre of mass 100% accurately , but the amount is so small that it is negligible.

However , in the second block , the energy was converted into a fair amount of both angular momentum and linear momentum .
We know that the total energy of both the objects are the same. So this would mean that linear momentum of the second block would have to decrease so that the total energy remains the same.This would mean that the second block would jump lower than the first block , because the first block converted almost all the energy into linear momentum .

But obviously ,the result was different. I think this is because the spin of the second block dragged the air around it downward , and by newton's third law , an equal and opposite force was generated which pulled it upwards , due to which both the objects reached the same height

I think this may be due to Newton's projectile approximation. It's about momentum transfer, not energy. The bullet stops when it moves the same amount of mass in the target and imparts the same momentum to it. There is the same amount of vertical angular momentum in both initially, but there is also intrinsic angular momentum in the geometry of setup2 initially. Momentum must be conserved, so both systems will have the same final vertical momentum, even though the second also has higher kinetic energy.

Total Mechanical Energy = Kinetic Translational + Kinetic Rotational + Potential Gravitational + Internal (Dissipative)

The total mechanical energy is a constant. You cannot destroy or create energy; it comes from somewhere and then goes elsewhere. In this case, the bullet penetrates the block of wood and becomes physically embedded inside it, causing deformation of the wood. This deformation is dissipative and non-conservative, meaning that the energy is used to deform and heat up the wood and cannot be recovered into kinetic or potential energies. In the case where the block is rotating, there is less deformation of the wood block by the bullet, meaning less energy is dissipated inside the block and instead that "extra" energy, if you will, is converted into rotational kinetic energy.

The conservation of energy only starts when the bullet is stuck inside the block (due to force of friction between the bullet and the block), so that means that the initial energy of the second block is both translational and rotational kinetic energy (starting from when the bullet is stuck). The rotational kinetic energy is maintained (if we ignore air resistance) so the kinetic energy (which is the same as the first block as a result of conservation of momentum; mv = (M+m)v' in this case) is completely converted into potential energy.  But if we do not ignore air resistance etc the second block won't fly exactly as high as the first one but a little less higher.

If you look at the ends of the block as the surface of a wheel, the spinning block has equalizing vectors. If you look at the upward force that started the spinning, there is a corresponding downward force. The center of mass is the same whether the block is spinning or not. The only loss of vertical energy is transferred to aerodynamic drag from the block spinning. At the slow speeds of this experiment, this drag would be extremely minor compared to the forces of gravity, such that it is not observable by the eye. The spinning block made 4 revolutions in the air before reaching the peak. If the height was 3 feet and the time to peak is .75 seconds (estimated based on time aloft), the vertical speed is 4 feet per second. the spinning block had 4 times that speed so 14 times the drag. That extra drag took energy from the total energy equation but was still very minor compared to the other factors that impacted the height of the block.

here's an experiment I would like to see if you can do...
Some time ago while doing some military training (we were using fake weapons) I put the buttstock of my weapon on my shoulder to point the weapon straight up in the air. Since I've taken plenty of physics courses and studied engineering in college I knew this was not a problem at all, but someone decided to come try and chew me out because of that claiming that if my weapon was to fire accidentally the round (bullet) would fall somewhere and it could kill someone.

Here is my claim: There is no possible way that round could kill someone. The round itself weighs 68 grains. That's .155 oz. The equivalent of a pebble. You know, the things kids threw at each other on the playground in elementary school.
The round travels upward at 2700 ft/sec upon leaving the barrel. Gravity then begins to work on the round until all that velocity is shaved off and it reaches 0 ft/sec. The round begins to fall back to the earth but because of air resistance the round will not reach 2700 ft/sec again. It will reach what is called "terminal velocity". It has no propulsion behind it anymore. just gravity pulling it down and air keeping it from continually increasing in velocity. The only way it could pass terminal velocity would be if the round rotated to point downward and the aerodynamics of the round allowed it to gain more velocity as a result. Still, there would be a terminal velocity because there is still air resistance despite aerodynamics. And that's assuming any kind of wind in the atmosphere on the way back down does not cause the round to rotate such that it is no longer pointing down.

A 5.56x45mm round from an M4 or M16 is not all that aerodynamic anyway. It is not a sniper round. It's maximum effective range is between 500-600 meters. The maximum range it will reach is 3600 meters.
considering the fact that it would take at least 600-800 feet per second to break skin and a round that size could not inflict enough kinect energy to cause a concussion or even a headache, there is no way (in my opinion) that round could kill when falling out of the sky. Unless the round is fired at an angle, then it has x velocity and has the potential to kill on impact. but when fired straight up into the air it will not have that x velocity. so all the velocity will bleed off as gravity pulls the round back down and it will reach terminal velocity on the way back down that is not enough to break skin and the mass of the round will not impact with enough kinetic energy to cause death.
So my claim remains that a round that size with not kill. Perhaps a .50 caliber round would, or something heavier simply based on the kinetic energy, but not something of this size.

I predicted both blocks would reach the same height! My reasoning was from probably the most incorrect place, i.e. my first-year statics textbook! We had just covered a chapter on resultant forces and moments, so I thought...

Both blocks experience the same resultant force - the impact from the bullet. The force on the first block is exactly along its centre of gravity, so no tendency to rotate - or moment around that point - was created. The second block, however, is hit from the side which does create a moment along its centre and causes the block to rotate. This, however, does not have anything to do with the resultant force and, seeing that the resultant force is what determines the height the block reaches, both blocks would reach the same height.

Probably way too idealized and maybe fundamentally flawed (I mean, the blocks aren't static at all!), but it led me to the right prediction!

I admit to answering too fast and being fooled by this one. There are two ways to understand the result. First we have to understand that the collision between the block and the bullet is completely inelastic. They don't bounce at all, but rather merge into a single unit. That means that some of the energy is lost to deformation and destruction of the wood fibers and the bullet, ultimately becoming heat. Since the off center block can respond to the collision by rotating away from the bullet's force, the bullet penetrates less deeply, and less energy is lost to inelastic heat. That energy difference goes into rotation.

Unlike kinetic and potential energy, which are not conserved when collisions are inelastic, (Think of dropping a ball of putty. All the energy goes into deforming the object.), momentum (the product of mass and velocity) is always conserved. The momentum of the system just before the collision is mV1, and the collision it is (M+m)V2, regardless of the on-center or off-center collision. V2, the velocity after the collision, will be the same in both cases, so the height will be the same in both cases.

Only two things are conserved: linear and angular momentum. That the former is conserved means this must reach the same height (give or take the difference in air resistance of the spinning block, which is negligible). That the latter is conserved causes the block to spin.

The energy consideration is interesting, though, as we can predict that the round will have penetrated further into the block that was hit centrally than into the offset block. However if you think about it that is obvious.

After the impact was over the centre of mass was moving the same speed in both cases, so the impact point, which was moving around that centre of mass, was moving faster than the centre of mass. It accelerated more easily (think of lifting one end of a mass rather than both) so there was less damage in doing so: that part of the mass moved faster more easily, so the round did not penetrate as far..

The spinning of the block is symmetric about an axis (the nail). Because the block is rotating in a circle no work is being done. You can think about this as follows: The right side of the block, which is half the block, is rotating up to a higher point at any given moment. This means it is gaining gravitational potential energy. However, the left side is rotating down by the exact same amount at the exact same moment, and it constitutes the other half of the mass. This is an equivalent loss in gravitational potential energy. All points on the block are rotating in a circle, coming back to their original point (while also being translated vertically upward). Because they travel in a circle no work is being done since Work=Force*DISPLACEMENT. Energy is defined as the ability to do work. If no work is being done there is no energy change due to the rotation. The only change is the vertical motion.

The collision is inelastic, which means that the kinetic energy IS NOT CONSERVED, but the total energy is.  Both blocks reaching the same height was a surprise to me, but the explanation lies in something we were not shown.  The inelasticity (coefficient of restitution) is different between the 2 blocks.  If we looked, I can guarantee you that the spinning block's bullet is not as deeply buried in the wood as the non-spinning block.  This means the internal energy (in terms of the work done making the bullet hole) is greater for the non-spinning block than the spinning block, which has greater rotational kinetic energy.  Thus, TOTAL ENERGY  is conserved, not Mechanical energy.

K trans+K rot+U grav+ E internal = K trans + U grav + E internal

Such that ∆ E internal = K rot

The total energy remains the same, it's just that in the first experiment more energy isn't transferred into kinetic or potential energy.

The blocks have differing rotational inertias about axis Z (we'll call that the spinning axis) and axis X/Y (the first shoot).  If you watch carefully, in the first part of the experiment, the block which we are told "does not spin," actually precesses about a different axis.  This axis has a higher rotational inertia (sluggishness to spinning) than the block about the Z axis.  This value can be thought of as a weighted average based on the square of the distance to the axis (search parallel axis theorem).  Now, in conclusion, the blocks both have the same energy at all times (of course assuming the bullet makes a perfectly inelastic collision and its energy is transferred completely and is normal to the surface of the earth (anti parallel to the direction of gravity) causing no velocity in the x direction at launch.  At the peak of each blocks arc, they have zero translational energy and the same gravitational potential energy.  The difference is in rotational kinetic energy, or is it?  No, they have the same rotational kinetic energy, but since it is about differing axes, the rotation occurs at different speeds.  If we would plot a graph of the distance the block was struck by the bullet from its center of mass (in both the axis to the right/left of the screen and in/out of the screen, vs the rotational speed about the X/Y or Z axis, we could more clearly see, and understand, this relationship.

I think the answer is how deep did the bullet go into the block. The deeper the penetration, the more kinetic energy is lost by the bullet which is converted into the work to spread the wood fibers apart. For the bullet aligned with the COG, there is more penetration and more "stopping power." The off center hit, the bullet does not penetrate as far, less "stopping power" and the excess energy is converted to rotational energy.

another thought. if this was an elastic collision, in the first case the bullet would actually bounce back so both the momentum and kinetic energy would be conserved, in a plastic collision kinetic energy is lost in heat/deformation. in the second case, in an elastic collision if we hit the block more and more off center, the bullet 'sees' less and less mass in front of it so it will bounce back less and less until we reach a point where the bullet stops and in this way it gives all its energy to the block, the idea being that the energy the bullet would have bouncing back is turned into rotational energy of the block

Because the bullet gets stuck inside the block and does not bounce off, this is an instance of an inelastic collision.  For inelastic collisions Kinetic energy is not conserved before and after (some of the energy is lost in deforming the block of wood and the bullet) and therefore cannot be used to predict the outcome of the event.  However, momentum is always conserved (the most sacred rule of physics). So take the bullet of mass M traveling upwards at a velocity of V1.  Its momentum is M*V1 in the Z direction.  After the collision the bullet becomes lodged into the block which has a mass of m, so MV1=(M+m)V2, so V2=V1*M/(M+m).  Immediately after the collision the energy of the block and bullet are 1/2*(m+M)V2^2.  This is converted to potential energy as the block moves upwards so 1/2(m+M)*V2^2=(m+M)*G*H where G is the acceleration of gravity and H is height.  So H=(V2^2)/2G=(V1*M/(M+m))^2/2G.  The only difference between the two cases is that one of them transferred energy into deforming the block and the other transferred energy into deforming the block and spinning it.  The key to this problem is recognizing that it is an inelastic collision and therefore momentum is the only conserved quantity.

This can be related to a statics question, When you hit the block on the side it creates a "moment" on the block (rotation) and an upwards force of "X" amount of Newtons (or pounds depending on which system you use). This system can be replaced with an equivalent system of "X" amount of newtons on the center of the block and a "Moment" on the block corresponding to the product of  the force applied on the side of the block multiplied by the perpendicular distance to the center of mass. Thus in this way you can create an equivalent system with the same upwards force and a positive moment (units of N*m and by convention counter clockwise). Hence by creating this equivalent system the body has the same vertical force being applied thus it the same potential energy and thus making it to the same height. YAY ENGINEERING! :D

The additional energy comes from the set up of the experiment.  In each experiment the block experiences an equal vertical component of force from the bullet.  If you were to draw a free body diagram you would have identical diagrams which means they will go to the same height given the same initial position.  However because the bullets path is off set to the center of mass of the block the second set up has angular momentum before they even make contact (given by the formula {r x p} where r is the distance between the bullet and the center of mass of the block, p is the linear momentum, and the angle theta is that made between the bullets straight line trajectory and its direct path to the center of mass of the object.  This is where the additional energy comes from.  It seems counter intuitive because before they collide neither object is spinning but if you look at the the entire system of block and bullet as the bullet travels towards the block you can see that there is some degree of rotation (draw a line between the center of mass of the block and the bullet for different positions along the bullets path, you can see that this line slowly rotates in the same direction as the block will rotate after the collision).  Because angular momentum must be conserved (separately from linear momentum) the block + bullet must spin/ rotate after the collision as well.

the source of the "extra kinetic energy" is the amount of momentum (or energy) which is lost due to the inelastic collisions. When the bullet hits to the middle of the block, it experiences an higher resistance force opposite to its projectile. So, the bullet travels inside the block further by loosing its energy due to plastic deformation. For the second case, in which the bullet hits to the side of the block, due to the extra degree of freedom introduced to the system, less resistance force is experienced by the bullet. Hence, instead of inelastically loosing its momentum (via travelling the same distance in the block), the bullet transfer its extra momentum to the rotational motion (travels a less distance in the block or spends its momentum less inelastically). If the penetration depth of the bullet in the wood block for the both cases is measured, it can be seen that the penetration depth for the side impact is shallower than the center impact.

Maximum height of brick is dependent only on this velocity, hence it is the same in both cases. For those, who still wonder where did the rotational energy come from: Try calculating kinetic energy of bullet before impact and kinetic energy of brick and bullet after impact (including rotation). You will get lowest number after impact. If you shoot a bullet in the center of the brick, remaining kinetic energy is transformed mostly on deformation (deeper impact) and heat. But if you shoot the brick on side, some energy is also transformed into rotation of the brick.

The correct answer is as follows:
When the bullet hits in the first case, you get a completely inelastic sentral collision between the bullet and the block. The energy in such a collision is not preserved, but the momentum is.
In the second case, you have a completely inelastic (non-sentral) collision. The energy is not preserved here either, however more so than in the previous case. The momentum is preserved in both cases.

(Preserved momentum gives you that the velocity of the bullet + the block = the velocity of the bullet times the mass of the bullet divided by the mass of the block and bullet. More neatly put: V2=(v1*m1)/(m1+m2) making the velocity and the altitude the same in both cases.)

Hence, no extra energy is made, just less energy is lost in the last scenario.

I'm sure physicists have pointed this out in comments already but here it is: The bullet-block collision is not an elastic process. You've got energy being dissipated through the rearranging  of the innards of the block, shock waves dissipating through the wood, all that jazz. So kinetic energy need not be conserved. What DOES have to be conserved is both linear and angular momentum. Both bullets have the same linear momentum, so both bullet-block systems must as well. So they take off at the same speed and rise to the same height. The offset of the second bullet from the centre of mass gives the second system an angular momentum, and that's conserved by allowing the second block to spin. Meanwhile the first system has no initial angular momentum so it does not spin. Each collision is bound by the conservation laws to produce these results; so each dissipates precisely the right amount of energy to make it so.

okay, so I'm not reading 6K comments. But before I look up the answer my take is this: (1) The Moment of Inertia for a block of wood is very small relative to the impulse of a fired bullet. (2) When the bullet is fired at CoM the impact time is shorter because the weight of the block is unyielding. This causes much more thermal loss than the second case. (3) When fired off CoM, the impulse causes a torque and thus and angular velocity. Because the Impulse is absorbed over a longer period of time, there is less thermal loss.  Conclusion: No energy is created however the loss to heat and to angular momentum are roughly equivalent within the uncertainty of the measurements. (Take it easy on me if I'm wrong, I'm self-studying physics in my spare time while working full-time)

So we have two competing ideas here, the conservation of momentum, and the conservation of energy.  Conservation of energy indicates that the spinning block will go less high, while conservation of linear momentum indicates that they should go to the same height.  So which wins? 

The key here is that in fact, energy is NOT conserved.  In either case.  Consider that when the bullet enters the wooden block, it tears through it.  During this process, lots of heat and extra energy is released!  The key is that if you shoot to the side, LESS energy is released, resulting in total energy (rotational and potential) at the top.  Why is less energy released?  When the bullet strikes to the side, the block is able to roll away from the bullet by rotating.  Like a boxer rolling away from a punch, this results in less damage being dealt to the block, and less heat released.  When the bullet hits straight on, the block just has to take it, so more damage is done, like a boxer taking a punch straight to the face.

No additional energy is created. What is happening here is simply the conservation of angular momentum. For the first block, the bullet hit the block along the center of mass. This means that the angular momentum of the different molecules of the block effectively cancel each other out. For the second block, the bullet hit the block off to one side. This created what could effectively be described as a lever arm. The angular momentum of the block to the left of the bullet was great than that to the right simply due to mass, hence the block spins. Energy is conserved because the blocks reach the same height. Angular momentum is conserved because the forces cancel out in the first block and start to spin in the second.

It's because while angular and linear momentum are conserved, they are conserved separately. When the bullet hits the block, it has the same linear momentum in both cases, and thus the final linear momentum (which gives the initial velocity of the block-with-a-bullet, which determines the height it goes) is the same. For those wondering where the energy went, mechanical energy isn't conserved in this interaction, as this is a totally inelastic collision. Most of the kinetic energy of the bullet didn't go towards the kinetic energy of the final block-bullet combination, but went into various other forms, like sound energy, heat energy, and the energy it took to deform the block. Thus, for the off-center bullet, some of that heat/sound/deformation energy went into rotational kinetic energy instead. Thus, total energy is conserved, but the mechanical energy of the block-bullet combination the second time is higher.

Torque, moment or moment of force (see the terminology below), is the tendency of a force to rotate an object about an axis,[1] fulcrum, or pivot. Just as a force is a push or a pull, a torque can be thought of as a twist to an object. Mathematically, torque is defined as the cross product of the lever-arm distance and force, which tends to produce rotation.
Loosely speaking, torque is a measure of the turning force on an object such as a bolt or a flywheel. For example, pushing or pulling the handle of a wrench connected to a nut or bolt produces a torque (turning force) that loosens or tightens the nut or bolt.
The symbol for torque is typically τ, the Greek letter tau. When it is called moment, it is commonly denoted M.
The magnitude of torque depends on three quantities: the force applied, the length of the lever arm[2] connecting the axis to the point of force application, and the angle between the force vector and the lever arm. In symbols:
\boldsymbol \tau = \mathbf{r}\times \mathbf{F}\,\!
\tau = \|\mathbf{r}\|\,\|\mathbf{F}\|\sin \theta\,\!
where
τ is the torque vector and τ is the magnitude of the torque,
r is the displacement vector (a vector from the point from which torque is measured to the point where force is applied),
F is the force vector,
× denotes the cross product,
θ is the angle between the force vector and the lever arm vector.
The length of the lever arm is particularly important; choosing this length appropriately lies behind the operation of levers, pulleys, gears, and most other simple machines involving a mechanical advantage.
The SI unit for torque is the newton metre (N·m).

We assume that the same amount of energy is transmitted to the boxes in both cases. In the first case, by applying the principle of conservation of energy, considering as t0 the moment the box goes off, and tfinal the moment the box reaches its maximum height h, we have:
E0=Efinal
U0+K0=Ufinal+Kfinal
If we consider that initially the box had no potential energy (U0=0), and that at the final state it has no kinetic energy (kfinal=0), we can simplify:
K0=Ufinal
1/2xmu^2=Wh
1/2xu^2=gh
therefore h=u^2/2g
In the second case, by applying the same principle we have:
E0=Efinal
U0+K0=Ufinal+Kfinal
The box again has no potential energy initially (U0=0), but its initial kinetic energy is dependent on the two motions the box is executing: one linear motion, and one rotary motion around its center of mass (K0=Klin+Krot). Also the kinetic energy at the final state is not zero, since the box is still rotating with the same speed (Kfinal=Krot), as air resistance is negligible. Because of this:
Klin+Krot=Ufinal+Krot
So Klin=Ufinal
and again we find that h=u^2/2g
In other words, in the second case, the energy from the rotation does not change, so it does not affect the height that the box will reach, as it will only depend on the initial speed of the center of mass of the box.

First of all, I have to point out that there is no scale behind the blocks to actually check that they go to the same height, which is remarkable considering that's the whole point of the experiment.

Now to the motion. The force by the bullet is the same in both cases, and by Newton's 2nd law that's the mass of the block times the acceleration of the centre of mass. It doesn't matter where this force is applied. So both blocks have the same acceleration of the centre of mass, and therefore start their free fall motion with the same initial centre of mass velocity, and therefore same translational kinetic energy Ktrans.

The bullet also applied a torque to the off-centre block, so it also starts its free fall motion with a certain angular momentum, which is conserved thereafter. So it has some rotational kinetic energy, which remains constant.

So let's write down the energy balance equation for each block. Let's call the non-spinning block A, and the other one B. First, for A:

Ktrans = mgh_A

and for B:

Ktrans + Krot = Krot + mgh_B

Since Ktrans is the same for both, and Krot is conserved, it follows that h_A = h_B.

You didn't put additional energy into the spinning block, you just put less torque in its rotation. If you apply the same force on the same block, you put the same energy. But when you hit it below the center, you make it spin real slowly because you put more torque in it. So the first block had this energy: translation energy which leads it to the maximal height, big torque and little rotation speed. When you multiply  the torque by the rotation speed it gives you power, and when you multiply it by  the little time it has been exposed to the pushing force from the bullet, you have the extra energy you're talking about. So basically you have spinning energy with big torque and little rotationnal speed, and translation energy with the maximal height for the first block. Let's apply this formula to our second block, it has a big rotation speed, so it has a litle torque (which can be explained by the distance from the center to the point where the force was applied) and big rotationnal energy. So our second block has spinning energy with little torque and high rotationnal speed, and translation energy with the maximal height. The conclusion is: They have the same energy, but they it's transformed in a different way. Eventually, the quickly spinning block would lose more energy than the slow spinning one due to the friction force from the air, but before it loses even 5% of its spinning speed, it'll fall to the ground. The concept of conservation of kinetic and potential energies holds up only for Elastic collisions where the colliding objects bounce off perfectly without loss of energy. This experiment is a case of perfectly plastic/inelastic collision. in this case, a part of kinetic energy is lost as heat, sound and mechanical deformities. The block which is shot off-center was more efficient in conserving the kinetic energy post impact. (I am guessing that since the bullet is imparting the energy through "impulse force" the shot made off-center has higher time duration in which force is applied thereby increasing the efficiency)

This does remind me of an inertial propulsion system I have considered before.
Imagine a cylinder shaped space craft, hollow. Science says if I am inside it and shoot a cannon ball from one end to the other, the craft will have moved forward even after the ball hits the far end. (ignoring heat and gunpowder,etc). The craft is only restored to its original position once I fetch the cannon ball and bring it to its starting place.
Thus, it is not supposed to be possible to 'swim' in space -- you need to eject matter or leverage something externally.

However, if we imagine a giant steel ball in the center of the craft, mounted on an axle perpendicular to the body of the craft, and our cannon ball glances off of it, transferring some of its linear momentum into angular momentum of this steel gyro. Then the result is unbalanced, giving us forward motion.

This is a classic example of inelastic collision. By the conservation of linear momentum, the momentum of bullet (which is same for both cases) is transferred to the blocks of same mass, hence the velocity of the center of mass for both blocks will be the same and they rise to the same height. It is important to note that the kinetic energy of the bullet is also being absorbed in the form of heat. In the second case, more kinetic energy is being transferred to the block, hence it can translate and rotate and less is being dissipated in the form of heat. In the first case however, more is being dissipated as heat and other forms. Nature does this to conserve linear momentum.

The first one is spinning too. The energy of a spinning object is proportional to angular velocity squared and its moment of inertia. E=Jω^2. The fact that they are spinning the same object does not guarantee that the moment of inertia stays the same, for example, moment of inertia for a hoop that is rotating around its diameter is J=0.25mr^2 while if it's spinning in its own plane, J=0.5mr^2. This means that the moment of inertia of the body in the first experiment is higher as it does a different type of spinning, and the rotational energy in the first experiment is equal to that in the second one even though the angular velocity isn't.

F=ma, and T=r x F. F is force, m is mass, a is acceleration, and T is torque. 
E=1/2*mv^2, and Erot=1/2*I*omega^2. E is energy, Erot is rotational energy, I is moment of inertia, v is velocity, and omega is rotational velocity. 
The torque that is applied from the bullet results in a nonzero angular velocity in the spinning case, and (since torque is zero in the non spinning case) there's a zero angular velocity in the non spinning case. 
At the same time the force results in a velocity upwards in both cases, each experiences the same force.
Notice how both the rotational case and the translational case are separate. The rotational energy didn't come from nowhere, it came from the same place the translational energy did. That does not mean that the translational energy is diminished in any way.

The extra energy for the rotation is simply energy that wasn't scrubbed away by friction when the bullet entered the block. 

When the bullet was fired straight into the center, an inelastic collision transferred all its momentum to the bullet-block system, which was manifest in the kinetic energy of the block's upward movement. Momentum was conserved, but ENERGY was not.

When the bullet entered off-center, the momentum exchange imparted an angular acceleration to the block. The force required to accelerate the block about it's axis of rotation is less than required to accelerate it upward, therefore the momentum exchange from the bullet to the bullet-block system scrubbed off less energy (the bullet didn't penetrate as far into the wood). The now lopsided bullet-block system now transitions from rotating about the center of the block system, to rotating about the center of the bullet-block system, which translates the remainder of the energy into the upward acceleration of the center of mass.

My theory:

(Long version)
I believe that since it's mass is distributed equally across the whole volume, it does not matter if it is spinning or not.

However, if it's mass would NOT have been distributed equally, then it WOULD matter if it's spinning.

Why? you might ask.
Simply because the less mass on one side or at one point that receives the energy, the more energy will be applied to that specific area,
which is converted to more kinetic energy, since less mass has less gravitational energy.

So if we say that the block would be hollow on the right side which it was shot at,
then the heavier side which would have greater gravitational energy than the hollow side, which would have more kinetic energy AFTER being shot at.

BUT!!!! Since the block has it's mass equally distributed, it will absorb the energy equally nomatter where you shoot it. And that energy will be converted (to some extent) to the same amount of kinetic energy no matter where you shoot it.

(Short version)
Equal gravitational energy throughout the whole block = equal energy absorption throughout the whole block.

Note that energy must always be calculated with respect to some coordinate system. In the first case, the bullet only has "regular" kinetic energy, whereas in the second case the bullet has rotational energy as well, since it is not moving in the same direction as it's direction from the origin of the system. This is the flaw of using energy here. In the same coordinate system, the bullet has different energies.

If I remember my mechanics right, it is due to conservation of linear and angular momentum. Taking the origin of the system at the center of the block, in the first experiment, all momentum is linear and gets transfered as such. In the second experiment, the bullet actually possesses angular momentum with respect to the center of the block, as well as linear momentum. Both momenta get transferred on inpact, resulting in a rotation and the same vertical motion. It's a matter of coordinates.

I ran out of room in the last comment, but I'd like to explain one last thing. The bullet that went into the center of the first block used it's kinetic energy to destroy more of the block and left as heat (not conserved). With the bullet shot to the side, kinetic energy was used less for destroying the block and exiting as heat, and more for rotating the block (angular momentum). But angular momentum wont change linear momentum (height). Angular momentum makes one block spin more than another.

Yes, this is actually a lot more simple than people are making it out to be. It's the law of momentum conservation. The amount of momentum in both bullets fired is the same, which means that the momentum of each block will be the same. The bullet loses momentum when it hits the block, and the block gains the same amount of momentum the bullet lost. Think of it as a transfer of momentum.

Combined with this law, your answer adds a perfect explanation to this experiment.

Equilibrium of the force Y:
Fyb-G=X

And in the block that got shot out of center it still remains:
Fyb-G=X

Therefore, if you consider time zero to be the instant the bullet hits the block, the rotational energy at max height and time zero can be cancelled out of the equation, as they never change. Both cases then receive identical force from the bullet, and identical force from gravity, making what we see equally identical.

To add to that... I believe the weight of the block becomes negligible when compared to the impact of the bullet.  Since force is mass times acceleration, and (assuming that) mass is constant and acceleration of the bullets (vs. gravity) are both constant...  to me the only solution is that in order to rotate the block it takes significantly less force when compared to the bullet resisting gravity vertically... thus being visibly no difference in height, but then again I have been wrong before.

If we think of the two blocks as point masses, their centers of mass will reach the same height.  If the point mass is spinning, that doesn't change its average center of mass.

The collision initially gives more momentum to one side of the block, causing spin, but the effect on the entire block as a whole is the same.

It's a trick question. As an inelastic collision, the total _mechanical_ energy is not conserved (some escapes as Heat). However, the total Momentum is:

p(before)=p(after) or

bullet_mass*bullet_speed+ block_mass*0 = (bullet_mass+block_mass)*V or 

V = bullet_mass * bullet_speed / (bullet_mass+block_mass). 

That is the velocity of the bullet-block aggregate right after the collision. 
Therefore, in both cases, the kinetic energy is the same and the blocks reach the same height :)

The energy used to rotate the block is the same as the energy needed to push the non-rotating block to the extra friction this block receives from the air above it. In other words, the rotating block has less air resistance.

It's not about the conservation of energy but momentum. Linear (p) and angular (L) momentum are conserved independent of each other. Conservation of p is easily understood but it's the conservation of L that confuses people and depends on where you measure the axis of rotation. 1st case: the radius is close to zero and so the angular momentum is small = slow rotation (none), 2nd case has a larger radius and so the system has greater angular momentum = fast rotation. Energy in case 2 is greater.

So summarizing: 1. Only momentum is conserved energy is not.2.Some of the energy that would be lost becomes rotational energy.3. Gravity cant make the block spin slower as net torque is 0.4 The blocks have same initial translational energy after collision by the impulse momentum theorem. 5. At the highest point all the kinetic energy does not become potential, only translational energy. 6. Work done is change in KE, and this change is the same for both which explains the same height.

Another thing nobody has mentioned yet: There is no net torque on the body when it is in the air, hence the angular momentum is constant. Therefore gravity cannot change rotational energy and  work done by gravity is changing the kinetic energy of translation. The error in this answer is that we are assuming that all  the kinetic energy becomes potential at the highest point, but only all the translational energy is getting converted into potential. The body always retains its rotational energy.

Energy lost in 1st collision is more than the 2nd one. Why? The bullet compresses the block radially outward, after which the block expands and travels upwards. Compression is a Coulomb force, which falls inversely over distance. If you think about it, you can then see why the bullet being in the center "compresses" the block more than the bullet being off-center. More precisely, the power in the 1st case is larger than the 2nd case. Less power means more "adiabatic" and hence less heat loss.

The collision of the bullet with the block is an inelastic collision. In an inelastic collision, kinetic energy is not conserved. Momentum is always conserved. In an inelastic collision, the difference between the energy before the collision and the energy after the collision is expressed as the heat that is caused by the collision. The angular momentum in the 2nd case comes from the off-center path of the bullet, and has no effect on the linear momentum, and thus on the height of block's path.

Momentum is a vector quantity, i.e., it has both magnitude and direction.  A spinning block has zero net momentum because the momentum of its constituent particles cancel out.  So, when the bullet is fired into the block, the momentum cannot be preserved by spinning the block; it can only be preserved by moving the entire block in the direction the bullet was travelling.

You can clearly see that at the point the line is displayed in the video, the center of mass is actually higher on the left side block, i.e. the block that is not spinning. That this is not noticed in the video is just insufficient measurement accuracy or a desire to create a provocative result. There are two different effects in play here: The spinning block loses altitude from some energy being diverted into spinning the block, but it likely gains from less drag. The loss to spin wins out.

On a second thought, I think it doesn't have so much to do with frictional force. The friction of the spinning block would be quite equivalent to the one that isn't. The spinning one will experience friction on all 6 sides, but the not spinning one will experience friction on only 5 sides (not on the bottom). The front and back (spinning counter-clockwise) will be the same for the other not spinning one. The spinning block's other 4 sides will experience equally distributed friction.

However, in the second case, the block has to rotate. When it is rotating, there will be less air pressure on the block when it is going upwards, since the air would be able to flow past the block as it goes diagonally downwards. This decreases the time needed to "fill up" the partial vacuum below the block, and thus increasing the KE with decreased resistance. So the faster the block turns (increased KE), the faster the replacing rate of the partial vacuum, thus cancelling each other out.

To calculate the change in velocity of a body, you sum the translational impulse(s) and divide by the mass; this gives you translational velocity. You then sum the cross products of the impulse(s) and their vectors from the centre of mass, and divide by the moment of inertia; this gives you rotational velocity.

How tiny is that energy? Well the rotating energy is given by E=1/2*Im*W^2. Im is the moment of inertia and is given by 1/12*m*(width^2+height^2)(you can look for it in Wikipedia) . W=2*pi*f and I counted in the slow motion footage 10 rotations in a second. Assuming a 250g block with 15cmx10cm (widthxheight) the rotating energy is Er=1.34 Joules. The bullet will therefore penetrate just an imperceptible tiny bit less when compared to the non-rotating block.

The rotating block does indeed has more energy than the non-rotating when they reach the highest altitude and this does not violates the conservation of energy b/c actually most of the energy of the bullet was not transferred to the block, but lost in heat, sound, etc. A 10g bullet at 300m/s has an energy Ec=450 Joules. A 250g block at 1m height has Ep=mgh=2.5 Joules. In the rotating block a tiny bit of this 447.5 Joules will actually NOT be lost and used to put the block rotating.

In the absence of an external force (no friction) momentum (P) is conserved . So, if the blocks are equal, the bullets are equal and so their velocity, than both systems have exactly the same momentum.  Furthermore Ptot=Mtot*Vcm where Vcm is the velocity of the center of mass. Since both systems have the same momentum and mass, the center of mass will have the same velocity. In other words both centers of mass will reach the same height.

Additional rotational KE is granted by dot product of vectors dW=T*d(phi). First and second block has equal linear KE (dW=F*ds) which is converted to PE, but rotational KE isn't converted to PE. The bullet doesn't need to know. With inelastic collisions, momentum (both linear and angular) are always conserved, but kinetic energy is not. The amount of kinetic energy lost to heat is always constrained by conservation of momentum. Only in a perfectly elastic collision would both momentum and kinetic energy be conserved, but that would have involved the bullet bouncing off the block in such a way that neither was damaged.

A more interesting question would have been, given the mass of the block, the mass of the bullet and the maximum height attained by the block's trajectory, work out the velocity of the bullet just before impact.

In the inelastic collision linear momentum is conserved, so the initial upward momentum of the block (and hence velocity) is the same in either case.  The off-center hit also has angular momentum about the center of mass, but so does the bullet before impact.  The simple energy arguments don't work because energy is dissipated by tearing up the wood.  What determines the ultimate height is the initial velocity after the impact, so that is determined by the linear momentum.

Just look at the momentum and external forces on the center of mass of the bullet-block system.

Initial momentum is the same in both cases.

External forces (just gravity) are the same in both cases. The sum of the external forces is the rate that momentum is changing with respect to time.

With the same initial value and the same rate of change for momentum (and velocity since the total mass is the same), the center of mass of the entire system follows the exact same path for both shots.

Friction consumed the addtional energy gained from spinning.

At the beginning, the bullet has vertical momentum.
When it hits the block, due to the law of conservation of momentum, the block (with the bullet inside it) has to have the same vertical momentum. Spin is not vertical momentum, so no matter how fast the block spins, it still will have the same vertical momentum.
Therefore the difference of energy must come from heat.

This is a perfect example of how energy chooses the path of least resistance. In the first block, the bullet has two main ways to transfer the energy, deformation and acceleration. In the second block there are three ways, deformation, acceleration and rotation. The amount of energy that is transfered from the bullets to the blocks are the same, however some of the energy used to deform the first block is used to rotate the second.

(cont.) But for the second block, which has a nonzero value of the distance to the bullet, it has torque working around the center of its mass (like a hinge). Thus, it is rotating the block in that counter clock wise direction, but the total energy on its vertical motion is conserved, as the force of torque acting on that point was reduced to zero in the first block, but nonzero in the second block.

The blocks had the same vertical motion, but they didn't have the same motion on the plane parallel to the bullet. With the same force, they have the same TME on the vertical plane, and thus the same KE and PE, but the torque (which exists on the plane parallel to the bullet) of each block is different. The perpendicular distance to the bullet for the first block is 0, so there is no torque.

I think what is happening here is that angular momentum and linear momentum are different, and both are conserved, but separately. For the first one, the bullet has a certain linear KE but zero angular kinetic energy (since it hits COM). For the off center, the bullet has the same linear energy, but a certain angular velocity, and thus angular KE. Same linear KE -> same height. 

Energy is conserved, but you can't go lump linear and angular together. It's a limitation of Newtonian physics.

So you're right that the Ea(wasted) = Eb(wasted) + Eb(rot). The reason is that there are 3 conservation laws: momentum, energy, & angular momentum. You can treat these 3 laws separately. If you do the ang. momentum you find that the 2nd block MUST spin. This then takes Eb(rot) from the remaining energy. The Eb(wasted) is just the left over [heat, sound, etc.]

If you draw a free body diagram of the system you see that the force in the vertical direction is the same in both cases. The case where they bullet is off center just has the added moment arm creating the spin. Think about if you had two guns, in one case you have both guns equidistant from the center on opposite sides and on the other you have them at the same point on one side. When you have both at opposite sides the moments cancel out, when they are on the same side, they are additive.

So the issue with this problem is that to fully understand what's happening you really need to look at each conservation laws: momentum, ang. momentum, and energy.

They both have the same kinetic energy since they have the same velocity (because of momentum). This energy can't be used for anything else. You can look at ang. momentum and find 2nd block MUST spin.

The fact that in the second case we have additional rotational energy is of no consequence. The bullet-block system is closed, because there is no exchange of matter with something outside. Therefore conservation of momentum applies and is therefore trivial to conclude that they will reach the same height. The extra rotational energy doesn't come from the initial kinetic energy, but the potential energy of the two elements.

Isn't it similar to the principal behind a lever?  Hitting it in the centre is using brute force, pouring all the energy into lift alone, while hitting it in the side is levering up the side first, which takes a lot less energy to get moving to start with, which means that even though some energy has been spent on making the block spin, because it's a more efficient use of the energy, it goes to the same height anyway.

System's Kinetic energy = Center of mass Kinetic energy + Rotation energy = E_cm + E_rot. The CM kinetic energy is the same on both cases because conservation of linear momentum gives the same CM velocity: mV_0 = (M+m)V_CM. By conservation of energy: E_mecanical = E_cm + E_rot = (M+m)gH + E_rot -> E_cm = (M+m)gH, because the rotation energy is the same on the bottom and on the top. This implies that the height H is the same on both cases, center and off-center.

2 reasons -
- the spinning block slows down the bullet more gradually and therefore the second block can absorb more of the bullet's energy; whereas in the first block more energy is lost as heat and sound (of impact).  
- The spinning block has less air resistance and will travel up through the air more efficiently. In order for the block to move there are 3 forces that need to be overcome: Inertia, Gravity and Wind (Air) Resistance. Air resistance is greatly reduced when the block is spinning.

They are most certainly different in equations. Energy is a scalar, and momentum is a vector. Their magnitudes are also different.
For linear: KE = mv^2/2, P = mv
For rotational: KE = Iw^2/2, L = r x P (cross product)

So the two systems have the same linear momentum (same m, v), but in the second setup, the bullet is to the side, giving the "r" term in rotational momentum a non-zero value.
Linear momentum is the same -> same height.
Rotational momentum different -> one spins, the other doesn't

To add what I could not fit in my response: With the balanced gravity of the first test, the initial gravitational force is equal on both sides, so it cancels itself.  With the second test, all of the gravitational pull on impact is focused to the left side, creating the extra energy for the spin

We have three basic conservation laws: energy, linear momentum and angular momentum. The law of conservation of energy is rather useless here since we don't know how much of the energy transformed into heat (plastic deformation). On the other hand, the conservation of linear momentum implies that the velocity of bullet-block after impact must be the same in both cases since the mass is the same: "v' = v m2/(m1 + m2)". This also explains why the block flies straight up, no sideways motion.

In the first test, the bullet hits the block in the center, meaning that the gravitation pull is equivalent on both ends of the block, and the block goes up with little rotation.

In the second test, the bullet hits the side of the block, meaning that there is unbalanced gravitation pull. The bullets energy transfers to the blocks height the same as in the first test, but this time, the with the unequal distribution of energy, the right side begins lifting before the left, giving the block spin.

We know the total energy of each block must be the same. 
We know both blocks have the same linear kinetic energy (vertical motion).
We know the spinning block has more rotational kinetic energy.
So the spinning block must have less of some kind of energy. I propose that it is thermal energy.

The bullet inside the non-spinning block is probably warmer than the bullet in the spinning block. The energy that heated the non-spinning bullet is the energy that spun the second block.

3) One sample of each test is insufficient.
4) Increase the variation to better isolate its effects. For example, add energy to the system or use a greater offset with longer boards.

The total rotational energy of the bullet-block system is zero by Newton's Third Law (equal & opposite forces), because for every bit of mass that has centripetal acceleration on one side of the block, another amount of mass exactly the same as the first has a centripetal acceleration in the exact opposite direction on the other side of the block. This is because centripetal acceleration is always toward the axis of rotation.

v1=v2=v= bullet speeds at two instances
m1=m2=m=bullet masses at two instances

m*v=(m+M)*V2

Conservation of momentum.
Initial momentum: p1 = m ( v1 )
Final momentum: p2 = ( m + M ) ( v2 )
v2 = m ( v1) / ( m + M )
^For both cases. This means that in both cases, the velocity of the block after the collision is the same. Since the only thing that determines how high the block goes is its initial vertical velocity, they go the same height.

Newton's third law is only valid for bodies acting in the absence of external forces. There is conservation of momentum in the Earth-gun-block system (it's always zero), but in a reference frame where the ground doesn't move, there is no conservation. 
Or, more mathematically, the y coordinate appears in the Lagrangian, so the canonical momentum conjugate to y is not a conserved quantity. Linear momentum is conserved on any plane parallel to the ground, but not perpendicular to it.

Basic physics...

Conservation of Linear Momentum - Both blocks reach the same height.

Conservation of Angular Momentum - The offset block will spin.

Conservation of Energy - The offset block has more kinetic energy and therefore less energy was dissipated as heat and sound when the bullet was driven into the block. In other words, in the offset case the bullet is less deeply embedded in the block. Total energy, kinetic + heat + sound + whatever, is always conserved.

It's conservation of linear and angular momentum. The bullet-block system has the linear momentum of the bullet's initial linear momentum, which is conserved in both collisions. In the second collision though, the bullet has an angular momentum relative to the center of mass of the whole system, which is also conserved, causing the block to spin. The collision is perfectly inelastic, so there's plenty of "wasted" energy in both collisions anyway.

In the second experiment, the part of the block that gets hit by the bullet recoils away faster than the rest of the block (because it starts rotating). It is also recoiling away faster than it would if the bullet had hit right below its center of mass. Because the block is "pulling away", the bullet doesn't penetrate as far into the block, and therefore less work is wasted as heat during the embedding process.

We need to see the block from another angle. "High" is only the z-axis of this 3 dimensional problem. IF the block was hit directly under the center of mass than it would go to the maximum z-axis position then fall back directly into the spot it began. Since the "center of mass" block does not, this means that there is a y-axis component to your movement vector. You can also see this component (with a different magnitude) in the off-center block experiment.

Going back to simpler physics, energy is lost in all in elastic collisions (such as this one) with a lot being lost to heat. Now, when the block is hit dead centre, more kinetic energy is lost as heat, since the entirety of the bullet's momentum is trying to transfer into the upward motion of the block. In the case where the bullet hits the edge, however, the resistance to motion decreases slightly, as the force required to rotate the block comes from part of the energy previously wasted as heat

So, thinking about linear momentum only, you come quickly to the conclusion that the block-bullet after the collision leave the support with the same linear momentum in both cases. Thus, the vertical rise must be the same.

When a bullet strikes the block below its centre of mass, the whole mass of the block opposes its acceleration so the maximum amount of energy is absorbed in penetration. But when striking off-centre, the block can rotate, allowing the point of impact to recede.  This provides less opposition to acceleration, so some of the energy is converted into angular acceleration (rotation), rather than penetrating so far into the block. More penetration into a firm target than a compliant one.

Let's consider the linear momentum of the bullet p = mv and the block with the bullet in it after the impact P = (M + m)V, along a vertical axis. According to the linear momentum conservation law, they must be equal p = P, not depending on whether the block is rotating. So, mv = (M + m)V, hence the initial speed of the block will be V = v * m / (m + M). We see it doesn't depend on whether is it rotating or not.

Assuming:
m=0.2 kg
height = 0.1 m
width = 0.15
height of block 1 m
rotation = 20 rad/s (3 rotations/s)

Rotational Energy U_r=½*I*w^2
I=1/12*m*(height^2*width^2) = 1/12*0,2*(0.15^2+0.1^2)=5.4 *10^-4
U_r=½*5.4 *10^-4*20^2=0.1083

Potential energy
U_p=h*m*g

h= U_r/(m*g) = 0.0552 m (5.5 cm)

Are you sure that you can measure this. It is difficult to increase I (moments of inertia) and keep mass constant to increase the differences, while keeping rotation constant.

This really has to do with Newtons first law. Quick, direct accelerations of mass are inefficient transfers of energy, similar to how it consumes more fuel to floor the accelerator of your car than accelerate slowly. In a similar way that tires waste energy when they spin out on asphalt, more KE is wasted turning into heat with the direct hit. Hitting a point offset the center of mass is a more efficient means of KE transfer and the efficiency bonus directly translates into rotational KE.

You're pretty close. Instead of working in terms of "force", the proper method is to use "linear momentum", particularly in the vertical direction. 

Using Momentum and Velocity instead of Force and Acceleration lets you ignore the details of what happens while the bullet is busy embedding itself and the wood is busy getting shot.

So a couple of things. 
1. Linear Momentum conservation: Assume the bullet embeds itself instantaneously, we would expect both block/bullet systems to have the same vertical velocity immediately following the impact.  Thus, equal height.

The reason is that the collision of bullet with wood is NOT AN ELASTIC COLLISION. In elastic collisions, both MOMENTUM and ENERGY are CONSERVED. With the bullet striking the wood, the collision is INELASTIC, and only momentum is conserved. So in each case, the mass x velocity of the bullet-block combo is the same. But in the second case, the bullet is buried less deep into the block (ask me why), LESS ENERGY is ABSORBED in deforming the wood, and the EXCESS is converted into ROTATIONAL ENERGY.

Both blocks have the same total energy. The spinning one simply has unbalanced energy.  The upward energy on the right side of the spinning block is greater than the average upward energy of the non-spinning block, and the average upward energy of the non-spinning block is greater than the upward energy of the left side of the spinning block by the same amount.  All energy is upward, and the average energy of both blocks are the same, thus the blocks reach the same height.

Macroscopic kinetic energy is not conserved in inelastic collisions.  The centre-hit block absorbs more of the bullet's kinetic energy as heat (microscopic kinetic energy), than the side-hit block, which absorbs some of that kinetic energy as rotational kinetic energy. The two blocks must reach the same height by conservation of (linear) momentum. Since momentum is conserved in any collision, the momentum of the bullet-block system in either trial is just the momentum of the bullet, which is the same in both trials. If both blocks start with the same linear momentum, then they also have the same translational kinetic energy, which is what is transferred into potential energy.
Of course any energy argument is invalid since this is not an elastic collision.

Momentum actually is conserved for both. Here's how:

When the bullet is shot off center, it actually has angular momentum relative to the block's center of mass, as well as upward translational momentum. Both have to be conserved, so the upward momentum of the bullet must move the block to the same height, while its (less obvious) angular momentum must also be conserved in spinning the block.

I suppose it has something to do with fluid dynamics. The block on the right is moving to the left while rotating counterclockwise. As a result, the top of the block is moving faster than the bottom of the block relative to the air. Using Bernoulli's Principle, we conclude that the pressure on the top is lower than that on the bottom. Hence there is a force from the pressure difference acting up. Another possible explanation is that the frictional force is smaller in the right block.

No energy is created.
The bullet's energy is just converted in two DIFFERENT ways:
In experiment #2, a part of the energy is used to create the spinning motion - whereas in experiment #1, this same part of energy may be used to make direct changes in the piece of wood structure (like creating a larger bullet hole, splits, or vibrations...)

When shot in the center, the block offers the maximum resistance to the bullet due to all its weight being balanced over the bullet's impact point. Because of this, the bullet digs further into the wood, loosing energy as it displaces more of the wood. When shot off-center, the wood rotates, offering less resistance to the bullet, causing the bullet to not dig in as far. The extra energy is translated into rotational energy, leaving the exact same amount of vertical force as with the other shot.

Rotational energy is zero!
Moment of inertia ( I = m × r² ) is zero because the distance to the rotational pivot r is zero, meaning no work ( I × α × θ ) is done due to inertia.

The applied force are the same magnitude and in the same direction for both blocks. This is also true for the gravitational force for both blocks. Though there is a difference in torques in the blocks, the forces and energy are equal for both.

This is called an inelastic collision: some of the initial energy of the system is lost to heat and sound, so we don't expect the initial kinetic energy of the bullet to equal the gravitational potential energy + the rotational kinetic energy of the bullet-block pair at its peak. We have to use conservation of momentum. The initial linear momentum of the bullet is the same in both cases, so the vertical momentum of the bullet-block pair after they hit is the same and will rise to same height

Key is that the bullet must stay in the block. Total energy transferred to the block is then (essentially) constant between both experiments. Important factors are then:

1. Deformation of the block by the bullet
2. Rotation of the block
3. Height the block reaches

Since the 2 experiments achieved the same height - rotation and deformation differences *must* net out.

Conservation of momentum is usually better to consider first in these sort of problems, because you have to consider every single possible form of energy.. Let us consider the conservation of energy on the Y axis. 

Let M be the mass of the block.
Bullet arrives with mass m and velocity v
Block leaves with mass M+m and velocity V.

By conservation of momentum, mv = (M+m)V
And thus V = mv/(M+m) , no matter where it hits. Having the same upward velocity, the block will go the same height, always.

Energy is a scalar quantity, there's no direction inherent. You also can't cite conservation of energy for a collision, because energy is always lost to the collision. The central shot gives more energy into burying the bullet deeper, energy which goes to the spin in the side shot. 

 Momentum is a vector, though, and a conserved quantity. The bullet has a certain momentum when it hits the block, and if it sticks together, the bullet/block system has the same momentum in either case.

A transfer of momentum causes loss of energy in the system. The centered bullet transferred all of its momentum at once, while the off center bullet transfers less momentum at impact, and the rest during rotation. Rotation causes a whipping effect that transfers rotational momentum to linear movement (ie throwing knives)

The centered bullet adds a bit of vertical rotation to the block (presumably from the rotation of the bullet as it exits the barrel).  This kinetic energy to spin vertically is overcome by the gyroscopic effect of the off-centered shot, and therefore it adds that energy from the bullet spin to height instead.  I don't know how, but I think that's what's happening.

I think it is lever. Assuming that the only vertical force applied to the block is the bullet (Fb) and gravity (m*g), the resulting force will always be Fb - m*g and it will always go as high. However in case 1, the block applies m*g to the bullet, whereas in case 2, because of lever, the force applied by the block to the bullet will only be (fraction of m)*g, with the rest of the force converted to rotation to maintain overall energy conservation of the block bullet system.

If you try to explain it using conservation of energy, then you have to take into account all contributions. You don't mention the energy that goes into the deformation of the block. In the second case the block will be slightly less deformed and instead have a rotational displacement. So in the second case the energy is converted into deformation+transl.+rotational kinetic energy while in the first case there is a (larger) deformation + transl. kinetic energy and no rotational kinetic energy.

Simplest to consider centre of mass (CoM) motion. After the bullet is fired, there are no external forces on the system other than gravity. The CoM of the block/bullet will then move as if it were a point particle of mass the combined block/bullet mass and initial momentum the combined block/bullet momentum. Wherever you fire the bullet from, this initial momentum is the same, so CoM moves in essentially the same way. Energy is not conserved in either case but more energy is lost in first case.

½mv²+½Iω² is *not* the initial state. The initial state is ½nu² (where n is mass of the bullet and u is it's speed). So if we ignore heat, we get ½nu² = ½mv² = mgh in the first case and ½nu² = mgh + ½Iω² in the second. To make those work we need to take into consideration non-mechanical energy, and so: ½nu² = mgh + E and ½nu² = mgh + ½Iω² + E'.

Mass of block = M; Mass of bullet = m; Velocity of block+bullet = V; Velocity of bullet = v.
Conservation of momentum gives mv = (M+m)V which gives V=m*v/(M+m);
Kinetic energy before collision: m*v^2
Kinetic energy after collision: (M+m)*V^2 = m*v^2*m/(M+m)
Since m/(M+m) < 1 we have lost energy during he collision. This energy has gone to destroy the wood, create energy and rotate the block. Different amounts of this energy goes to rotation of the block depending where the bullet hits the block.

The collision between the block and the bullet is perfectly inelastic (assuming that the bullet stays inside the block). Thus, energy is not conserved during the collision. Assuming that each block was identical to a tenth of a gram, commercially produced firearm rounds have some variation from shot to shot. A 0.5% variance on a bullet with a stated 3,000 joules of energy would vary by 15 joules.  Some rifles, you can get that much variance with about 0.6 mg of difference in the powder load.  So, you'd need to do about a hundred repetitions of each and plot the results to account for the error inherent in commercial ammo, which can be more like 8% off.

I think the problem is that everyone assumed it was a perfectly inelastic collision. It's not. When the bullet impacts the block at the CM, vertically, all of the force vector on impact translates the block upward. But the wood fibers break and compress, absorbing energy. When shot to the side, a smaller component of the vector on impact acts vert. while the horz. comp spins it. However, because the impact is weaker, compress. is less. The transfer of momentum is more efficient in the second.

A Rough calculation:
Assume dimension of the block: 12cmX7cmX3cm = 252cc
Assumed density = 0.9 gm/cc
Mass of block (m) = 0.9 * 252gm=0.2268 kg
Moment of Inertia (I) =  0.5 * 0.2268 * (0.12^2 + 0.07^2) = 0.002189 kg*m^2
Assume the appx max. height (h) the block reaches to be 0.7 m.
So, time it took the block to reach max height=sqrt(2*h/g)=0.383s
No. of rev. = 5
angular speed (w) = 5*2*pi/0.383=12rad/s
angular Kinetic Energy (KE) = 1/2*I*w^2 = 0.01313Joul
equivalent height = KE/(m*g) = 6mm

You're right. What stumped people (myself included) was the angular momentum. Angular momentum is the cross of the linear momentum (vertical momentum from the bullet) and the position vector from the center of mass. When shot at the center, this cross is zero since the vectors are parallel. When shot off center, the vectors are not parallel meaning there is torque. That torque gives the block an angular momentum which is conserved. I guess Destin forgot about the cat drop video he did ;)

So the 'extra' energy was always there.

As for the energy issue, in inelastic collisions, mechanical energy is always lost (to heat, sound, etc.) - in fact, in perfectly elastic collisions, as much energy as possible is lost while still conserving linear and angular momenta. In the case of the spinning block, the angular momentum is higher, requiring more energy to be conserved. Thus, less energy is lost with the spinning block.

The same height thing is easily explained: It's the same two objects (block and bullet), starting with the same initial velocities (zero and muzzle velocity, straight up). In both cases, the bullet sticks to (i.e. sticks inside) the block, so both cases are perfectly inelastic collisions. Conservation of linear momentum ignores the exact location of the collision, as long as the masses and velocities are the same, so the linear speed (and thus, the height it reaches) should be exactly the same.

It is a plastic collision - Only momentum (linear and angular) is conserved just before and after impact (gravity can be ignored for this short period). MECHANICAL ENERGY is NOT conserved.. Mass of block M mass of bullet m. v=muzzle velo..u=final velo.. Irrespective of where it hits: mv = (M+m)u or u = mv/(M+m). So both reach same height...In second case there is LESS loss of mechanical energy compared to 1st case...no energy is actually created!!!

I think the idea is that the bullet and block SYSTEM has conserved translational and rotational momentum. As soon as the bullet leaves the gun, the system has a nonzero angular momentum, L = r x p, where r is the approach distance (lever arm) from the bullet path to the center of mass of the block. Once the block is hit, the system conserves angular momentum about the bullet+block moment of inertia by spinning.

Since this was an inelastic collision, conservation of energy doesn't apply. Instead, look at the forces involved. The bullet undergoes a change in momentum (impulse, J). J = Δp = FΔt. For a period of time, t, the bullet exerts an average force, F, on the block in the vertical direction. The only significant forces acting on the block are gravity and the average force exerted by the bullet. Torque doesn't affect vertical acceleration, so the block would reach the same height both times.

Momentum (angular and linear) are conserved about the center of mass of the system (bullet AND block). Both scenarios had equal linear momentum (therefore equal height), but the offset shot had nonzero angular momentum as well.
