Angular momentum and linear momentum are conserved always.  Consider if we have 2 equal masses about a mass-less rigid string; if we fire at the center of the string, the masses go up.  If we target just one of the masses, we see that mass goes up and by the interaction with the string we see an angular momentum transfer from one mass to the other resulting in rotation (the other mass goes down), but the linear momentum is the same as the first system, meaning they will go up at the same rate

Principles of conservation of energy states that the total energy of an isolated system cannot change. The total momentum of the bullet hitting the wooden block does not change whether you hit the block to the center or to the side and it will all be transferred to the block. 

m(bullet)*v(bullet)=m(block+bullet)*v(eventual speed of block flying up)

And we should be able to calculate the height of the block flying up through:

v^2=u^2 + 2*a*s (where a=-9.81ms^-2; u=0m/s, S=height)

Since it's a perfectly inelastic collision, kinetic energy is not conserved.  The end of the block accelerates faster (in the second case) than the center (in the first case) and so the bullet slows down less/doesn't penetrate into the block as far, dissipating less energy.  This extra energy (that wasn't dissipated) is where the rotational kinetic energy comes from.  It also doesn't violate conservation of linear momentum, as it would have if it had not risen as far.

The spinning is caused by the moment of force (M) which is created by the force of the bullet not being in line with the spinning axis. As M=F*r Where M is the moment of force, F the actual force in Newton and r the length of the lever arm in meters. r is devined by the shortest distance between the spinning axis and the axis the force is pointing in. Because the force was in line with the spinning axis the first time, r was 0 thus no moment. But the second time r>0 thus creating moment/spin.

There is no trick here. The system actually did have more energy to start with when the bullet was on the right because it had angular momentum, which is given by the cross product r x p, where r is the position vector of the bullet and p is the momentum of the bullet.  Therefore the bullet HAD to have additional energy in the offset scenario.  Because both angular and linear momentum had to be conserved, the block rose to the same height but did NOT gain any unaccounted additional energy.

This is an inelastic collision. The vertical height traveled is determined by the momentum of the system. Momentum cannot be lost (why the height stays the same) but kinetic energy can be lost (k, energy is not created or destroyed but it is transformed into heat and sound energy).   The off center system is slightly less inelastic therefore conserving some of the kinetic energy and transferring by torque to rotational energy. The off center bullet will have a slightly shallower hole.

In an inelastic collision, kinetic energy is not a conserved quantity, however momentum is. The blocks travel to the same height because the both receive the same amount of translational momentum. 
In both cases energy is lost due to the deformation of the block and internal heating of the block. More energy is lost this way when the block is struck in the center. Presumably, the bullet penetrates deeper into the block in this case.

In both situations, the block spun with a constant rotational velocity (that means no net force acting on the block… so zero torque is acting on both blocks. If block is not spinning, that's rotational velocity = zero

Torque is force magnitude multiplied by the perpendicular distance from the force to the rotational axis

Since torque = zero in both situations, force is also = 0

So, no "extra" energy input into the bullet/block system.

Thus… Law of conservation of energy is not violated.

No energy from the bullet is used to spin the block. The block spins because one side of it is being pushed up by the bullet and the other is being held in place by gravity. This means that the spinning motion is not caused by the force of the bullet, but by the force of gravity on the other side. The extra energy at the end when the block is spinning is given to it by gravity.

Momentum in the up-down (y) direction is conserved in both block-bullet colisions. The speed of the center of gravity of a system composed of both the bullet and the block does not change with the collision, as the only forces acting are the bullet hitting the block and the block hitting the bullet (both internal system forces). Therefore, the speed going up after a collision is the same in both cases.

2) More kinetic energy is used to push the second block, while the first one is penetrated more.
3) More of the energy transferred to the first block is turned into heat.
4) The spinning causes the air around the block to behave differently, giving it a slight lift.
